body:
Yes, this is a good idea. I may be able to devote some time to this.
 @eickenberg I don't understand the filesystem structure you outlined
`kymatio/backend_common/complex.py`
`kymatio/backend_common/fourier.py`
`kymatio/backend_common/sampling.py` ?
Or something else?

That looks good and could work well I think. It depends on how much code we'll end up with. It could easily evolve from a `backend_common/backend_pytorch.py` to a file structure like the one you outlined (`backend_pytorch_fourier.py` etc). Or start there immediately. We might want to add the actual backend names as folders, instead of this sort of infix.

Hey, one more thing that could make sens is to use some OOP: one could make a parent class that implements common routines and provide the minimal environment to deploy other versions of the scattering, such as: 3D-gabor scattering, roto-translation scattering, roto-translation-separable scattering, harmonic phase scattering, video scattering, ..

For instance, .cuda(), .cpu(), forward(), J, meta, build(), psi, phi are examples of methods and attributes that could be reasonable shared.

issue.body:
Hi,

So StÃ©phane would be super happy to have a super fast differentiable scattering... who has the time to do this?(not me, I'm sorry about that) A simple unit-test to compare the gradients with torch backend is enough to validate the approach.

Best,
EO

body: Let's forget about OOP (we discussed it with michael). So, if this sounds OK, I'd like to do this via several progressive PR. I think the best feature to share, in a first step, is CDGMM as it's literally the same kernel for 1-2-3 D.
Agreed on `cdgmm`. `Modulus` is up there, too.
Okay, waiting that one merges several branches before doing anything. I'm a bit concerned by "modulus stable" in 1D, is it really changing anything or is this an overkill?

> I'm a bit concerned by "modulus stable" in 1D, is it really changing anything or is this an overkill?

From what I understand, it makes sure we have differentiability at zero. That being said, I haven't tested it.
would be awesome to confirm and if yep, adding it to 2D as well
Yes. And 3D. This is on my TODO list.

issue.title: `cdgmm` doesn't check that both inputs are on the same device

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body: This is at least true for the 2D torch `cdgmm`. It only complains when you try to multiply tensors. We should throw an error instead.

body: instead to create a `common_backend`, I propose to create a folder at the root of the software as I did for `frontend`
is this issue still relevant? i see no plan for dimension-agnostic backends in the currents PRs

It seems like we are waiting to release Kymatio v.2 then we'll start work on the common backend. 

(Personally, I'd be down to work on the unification of the backends over my winter break, even if v.2 is still in review. )

OK! Presumably that unification won't affect the API, so it's totally OK to defer it to a later stage of dev (v0.2.x or v0.3+).
I just wanted to make sure that it was not getting out of sight given all the outstanding work that you've been putting together towards re: v0.2 !!

> Let's forget about OOP (we discussed it with michael). So, if this sounds OK, I'd like to do this via several progressive PR. I think the best feature to share, in a first step, is CDGMM as it's literally the same kernel for 1-2-3 D.

Is this opinion still the same, or might the opinion on having some OOP have changed? I know earlier in a PR (I think #449 ) we were talking about further refactoring the backend in a future update (switching away from the named tuple stuff). Maybe we want to quote that discussion here (I cannot seem to find it)?
This will be done later, the backend begins being pretty pretty flexible

From @MuawizChaudhary, on `fft1d_c2c` etc. in 1D:
```
Maybe we want to do what we do in the 2d and 3d scattering transform, and pass in which FFT we are doing as a string?
```
